docs.lead_paragraph: Thomas B. Stoddard, a lawyer whose persuasiveness and erudition advanced the cause of equal rights for gay men, lesbians and people with AIDS, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48. The cause was AIDS, said his companion, Walter Rieman.

headline.main: Thomas Stoddard, 48, Dies; An Advocate of Gay Rights

docs.abstract: Thomas B Stoddard, lawyer and gay rights advocate, dies at 48; he was exec dir of Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund in New York from 1986 to 1992; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Thomas B. Stoddard, a lawyer whose persuasiveness and erudition advanced the cause of equal rights for gay men, lesbians and people with AIDS, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.    The cause was AIDS, said his companion, Walter...

docs.lead_paragraph: American workers downsized, re-engineered and shoved into salary ruts -- are slowly beginning to climb back up. Last year, they won wage gains that were the largest since 1990, keeping them ahead of inflation for only the second time in a decade. Modest though these raises were, many economists expect them to continue. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said recently that the era might be drawing to a close when workers were so worried about losing their jobs that they were afraid to demand raises.

headline.main: In Era of Belt-Tightening, Modest Gains for Workers

docs.abstract: American workers won modest wage gains in 1996 that were largest since 1990, keeping ahead of inflation for only second time in decade; many economists expect gains to continue; hourly wages, in current dollars, are rising at annual rate of 3.8 percent, about 0.5 percent above inflation rate, to average of $11.98; there are no signs that raises are proving inflationary, even in tight labor markets with low unemployment; graphs; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it may seem nonsensical for doctors who own their health maintenance organization to join a labor union. Nonetheless, about 2,000 doctors in MDNY, a physician-owned H.M.O. on Long Island, announced yesterday that they were joining the Office and Professional Employees International Union in what was more a marriage of convenience than the traditional relationship in which workers flock to a union for help in bargaining for a contract.

headline.main: Physicians in Labor Union? H.M.O. Doctors Make Move

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 30 Palestinian Women Are Released by Israel After more than a year of delays and a day of last-minute legal challenges, Israel freed 30 Palestinian women from prison, carrying out part of its agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization. To pacify Israeli hard-liners, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would seek pardons for Jews who killed Arabs. A3 Iraq Said to Smuggle Oil United States Navy officials said Iraq had been exporting oil, with Iranian help, in violation of United Nations sanctions. They said the Iraqis and their Iranian protectors had had two confrontations with Navy warships in the past two weeks, ramming a United States frigate in one showdown. But the officials said the smugglers often avoid American warships by hugging Iran's shallow, treacherous coast. A7 Ecuador Gets Newest President The President of Ecuador's Congress, Fabian Alarcon, was named President of the country for the second time in under a week. His first promotion came the night that the elected President, Abdala Bucaram, was ousted, but was eventually set aside in favor of the Vice President, Rosalia Arteaga. After the vote, Mrs. Arteaga returned, angrily, to the Vice Presidency and called for a plebiscite on who should run the country. A9 Peru Talks With Rebels A Peruvian Government negotiator met face to face with rebels holding 72 hostages in the Japanese Ambassador's compound in Lima. The talks, the first of their kind in over six weeks, took place in a house across the street from the compound. Representatives of the Red Cross, the Vatican, Japan and Canada took part. A8 Croats Force Out Muslims Croats in the divided Bosnian town of Mostar evicted some 100 Muslims from their homes, hours after firing on 200 Muslims who were visiting a cemetery at the end of the holy month of Ramadan. NATO-led forces and United Nations police began patrolling the streets to prevent more violence. The Mayor of Croat Mostar said the Muslims were disguised soldiers. A11 Charges for Honduran Ex-Chief Prosecutors in Honduras said they would charge a former President, Jose Azcona Hoyo, with illegally extraditing a drug trafficker to the United States. The case grew out of the kidnapping, torture and murder of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico in 1985. The Honduran Constitution says no citizen can be turned over to a foreign country. (AP) China Seals Off Muslim Town China sealed off the northwestern town where at least 10 people were killed in a Muslim separatist riot. An exiled leader said the troubles were set off by the public execution of 30 ethnic Uighurs. (Reuters) NATIONAL A12-22 Clinton and Congress Seek Agreements on 5 Issues President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed to try to agree on five issues: a tax credit for employers who hire people off welfare; education; tax cuts for individuals; juvenile crime and juvenile justice, and using the District of Columbia as a laboratory to test new ideas for education, employment and economic growth. They did not agree on changing campaign finance laws, health insurance for children or toxic waste disposal. A1 Campaign finance reformers faced other difficulties on Capitol Hill. Democratic and Republican leaders clashed on the terms of an investigation into the alleged abuses that occurred during the 1996 campaign. And supporters of a bill to revise the laws worried that it seemed to be losing momentum. A1 Hearings for Nominee Delayed The chairman of a Senate committee postponed hearings on the nomination of Anthony Lake to lead the Central Intelligence Agency until March 11. He said there were many ''unanswered, perplexing questions'' about Mr. Lake's conduct as national security adviser during President Clinton's first term. A19 A Losing Cosmological Bet Dr. Stephen W. Hawking, the cosmologist, conceded defeat in a famous bet he made six years ago with two professors at the California Institute of Technology. He bet that naked singularities -- places other than the centers of black holes where space and time are infinitely distorted and matter is infinitely dense -- could not exist. A scholar in Texas showed that, in theory, they could. A1 Hubble Repairmen Blast Off Seven astronauts aboard the shuttle Discovery blasted into space, heading for the Hubble Space Telescope. They are scheduled to replace two aging scientific instruments with more up-to-date ones and give the telescope a tuneup. A12 Trial Opens in Racial Killing North Carolina prosecutors began presenting their case against a white former Army private. They said he teamed up with a compatriot to kill a couple in Fayetteville in December 1995 because the couple was black. A12 Pooch Wins a Reprieve Portsmouth, N.H., pardoned Prince, a black Labrador mix who had been on death row since August for killing a rooster. But the agreement requires that a home be found for him outside Portsmouth. A15 Knife Brings a Suspension A high school honor student in Gobles, Mich., was suspended for 10 days for bringing a knife to school. She said it was a kitchen knife that she planned to use to cut a friend's birthday brownies. School board members said the action showed they were serious about weapons in schools, even though the student, Amber Nash, did not plan to use the knife as a weapon. (AP) NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 City Women's Shelter Replaces Its Entire Staff The entire staff of the only shelter for battered women run directly by New York City was replaced. Investigators said the shelter's workers had forced women to have sex, used drugs and alcohol on the job and allowed abusive husbands and boyfriends into the shelter at night. A1 Dinkins Decides Against Race Former Mayor David N. Dinkins told associates he would not run for Mayor this year. Some of the associates said he would probably endorse the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, instead. B1 Battle to Control Adelphi U. The trustees of Adelphi University won a court order blocking their removal by the State Board of Regents. The board, which put new trustees in power on Monday, said it would appeal. Each side said its trustees were in charge in the meantime. B1 Workfare Chief to Go Private Richard J. Schwartz, the architect of New York City's workfare program, announced he was leaving City Hall. He will form a consulting company to work with state and local governments on overhauling welfare systems. His career change illustrated the profit-making opportunities that have arisen from the new Federal welfare law. B3 HEALTH C8 Starchy Diet May Be Harmful People who eat lots of potatoes, white bread and white rice in the mistaken belief that it is the best way to follow a low-fat diet may do themselves more harm than good: the diet may increase their risk of diabetes, a study found. The researchers recommended eating more fiber. C8 SPORTS B14-19 LIVING C1-7 ARTS C9-18 Independents in the Oscars Independent films like ''The English Patient,'' ''Shine'' and ''Fargo'' dominated the Oscar nominations. Some of Hollywood's biggest studios, like Warner Brothers and Universal, were virtually shut out of top nominations, as was Madonna. C9 BUSINESS DAY D1-21 Business Digest D1 OBITUARIES B13 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Kofi Annan's cautious style, right moves at Adelphi, money as punishment, best-actress awards. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Frank Rich. Chronicle B8 Crossword C18 Weather D20

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed today on a five-item list of issues, from the quite specific to the very general, where they hope to work out agreements. The list comprised a tax credit for employers who hire people off welfare, education, tax cuts for individuals, juvenile crime and justice and using the District of Columbia as a laboratory to test new ideas for education, employment and economic growth.

headline.main: Clinton and Republican Leaders Agree on Five Goals

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Congressional leaders, meeting on Capitol Hill, agree on five issues where they hope to work out bipartisan accords; issues are tax credit for employers who hire people off welfare, education, tax cuts for individuals, juvenile crime and justice and using District of Columbia as laboratory to test new ideas for education, employment and economic growth; Republicans ignore Clinton's call to include campaign finance reform; Vice Pres Al Gore attacks Sen Trent Lott's call to include bill dealing with Superfund program to clean up toxic waste; Republicans reject Sen Tom Daschle's proposal to include bills to expand health insurance for children; leaders of both parties hail meeting; Gore, Lott, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Daschle comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Bernard Liautaud started Business Objects, a software company, he applied a simple formula that he naively thought might stir the imagination and shake the torpor of his country: dump French habits and do things the California way. The results were spectacular. Founded in Paris in 1990 with $1 million of venture capital, the company was worth close to $1 billion by early last year.

headline.main: For France, Sagging Self-Image and Esprit
headline.kicker: LIBERTY, EQUALITY, ANXIETY: A special report.

docs.abstract: Special report, Liberty, Fraternity, Anxiety, finds France, which remains rich and enjoys international importance beyond its wealth, is racked by corrosive anxiety and introspection; unease appears linked partly to rigidity of highly centralized system, in which nation's technocrats, who planned and managed country's reconstruction after World War II, appear overtaken by global economy and seem ill-adapted by formal training to its challenges; political elite is widely seen as group of cloned eggheads, out of touch with population, and labor unions, parading in rags of exhausted socialist dream, often seem equally fossilized; there is pervasive sense that not only jobs, but also power, wealth, ideas and national identity itself are migrating permanently, and at disarming speed; rapid technological innovation, radical strategic shifts, Internet and global market that have contributed to optimistic mood in US, have cast ominous cloud in France, where globalization is portrayed as death of national culture and high unemployment is attributed to untrammeled market forces and immigration; economy grew slightly more than 1 percent during past year, and unemployment rate has swelled to 12.7 percent, or more than double rate in US; photos; graphs (L)
docs.snippet: When Bernard Liautaud started Business Objects, a software company, he applied a simple formula that he naively thought might stir the imagination and shake the torpor of his country: dump French habits and do things the California way.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is always comforting to find a villain in a story of organizational failure and the Internal Revenue Service's computer modernization debacle presents a ready candidate: Richard M. Nixon. In the mid-1970's, with the wounds of President Nixon's attempted subversion of the agency still raw, Congress was given a choice of what kind of I.R.S. it wanted: huge, powerful and efficient, or huge, powerful and inept.

headline.main: How an Agency Was Left Behind on the Road Ahead

docs.abstract: Current $4 billion computer modernization fiasco at Internal Revenue Service is traced to Congress's decision in mid-1970's to weaken IRS by not providing funds for new computer systems and master plan for coping with explosive growth in tax return volume; experts say IRS, with its culture of secrecy, misplaced faith in its own expertise and inability to sharply define its mission, bears biggest share of blame; photos; tables (L)
docs.snippet: It is always comforting to find a villain in a story of organizational failure and the Internal Revenue Service's computer modernization debacle presents a ready candidate: Richard M. Nixon.    In the mid-1970's, with the wounds of President Nixon's...

docs.lead_paragraph: With their longtime control of extortion and bid-rigging rackets in New York City and New Jersey weakened by years of relentless prosecutions and by regulatory crackdowns, the region's Mafia crime families are switching increasingly to white-collar crimes as ripe sources of plunder, law enforcement officials say. The new Mafia focus is primarily on multimillion-dollar frauds in three lucrative businesses: health insurance, prepaid telephone cards and small Wall Street brokerage houses, according to law enforcement experts on organized crime.

headline.main: OFFICIALS SAY MOB IS SHIFTING CRIMES TO NEW INDUSTRIES

docs.abstract: Law enforcement officials say Mafia families in New York metropolitan area, with longtime control of extortion and bid-rigging rackets weakened by years of relentless prosecutions and regulatory crackdowns, are switching increasingly to white collar crimes as ripe sources of plunder; say new focus is primarily on multimillion-dollar frauds in health insurance, prepaid telephone cards and small Wall Street brokerage houses; say mobsters and associates, especially younger ones, have searched for new criminal opportunities in recent years as many of most powerful Mafia bosses have been sent to prison and flow of loot from traditional rackets has dwindled; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF it ever rains here, people like Miho Shimizu will be well prepared. Miss Shimizu, a 21-year-old college student, has been saving for a rainy day since she was a young child, and so has just about everyone else in this windy, rice-growing city on Japan's west coast.

headline.main: In Japan, Bankers Make House Calls

docs.abstract: Saving, a cultural norm in Japan, is reinforced by aggressive promotion by banks and a high cost of living; banks offer gifts and house calls to pick up deposits as incentives, and a national advertising campaign preaching the benefits of building a nest egg has been in place for years; photos (M)
